title: The Judge’s Breath
description: Up along the Whispering Aqueduct, where the river’s breath becomes a voice in stone, the Sunken Steppe Terraces tilt their weathered faces to a sky that remembers both flood and famine. Lantern-blue dusk settles in the carved stair-villages as the festival of weighing approaches, and every reedboat lies moored like a patient thought at the edge of a sentence not yet spoken. In the night, deft saboteurs crept across slick masonry and cut the bell-strings that summon the River Judge, hoping that silence would drown the plea of those who live by timing and tide. Rae Fen, who learned to hear pipe-murmurs as if they were kin, begs your hand and steadiness to retie what was severed and to defend the bell-ringers whose pulses keep the terraces in rhythm. You carry truths etched in hush and silt: the hidden bleed-valves and falsified flows that have starved upstream steps and fattened city cisterns. If the Judge rises to silence, the river will not call it mercy; it will call it a debt collected with interest, and whatever follows will run in salt as much as in water.
objectives: Travel upriver to the seventh terrace and meet Rae Fen at the bell shrine.
Repair or replace the severed bell-strings before flood-swell.
Present evidence of hidden bleed-valves gathered in M2 and M4 during the rite.
Protect the bell-ringers from saboteurs during the ceremony.
Assist Ys Hul in sanctifying a temporary rebalancing of sluice gates.
Escort the procession’s testimony to be recorded at the Aethral Archive.

dialogue.speaker: Rae Fen
dialogue.lines: I learned to hear my name in pipes, and now the river is saying the city’s name through my teeth with a tremor that tastes of brass. The bell-strings were cut by hands that know how to climb wet stone, how to breathe between beats, and how to hide ink under seals that look cleaner than prayer. Help me tie them again with knots that remember the right measure, and stand with the bell-ringers when the swell comes up the steps like a patient animal looking for its keeper. The terraces have long memories and short ropes; when a child goes hungry, the stairs themselves complain, and tonight they are groaning as if every rung were a throat. Help me ring something truer than hunger, something that carries across the plates and reeds and into the Judge’s quiet where truth does not echo but settles like silt.

dialogue.speaker: Ys Hul
dialogue.lines: We will call the Judge with sound and with silence held in balance, the way the terraces taught us before charters taught us to measure our neighbors by debt instead of rainfall. Bring your ledger of bribes even if it burns your hands, bring your map of valves even if the lines cut your eyes, and bring your courage even if it shakes like a leaf on the river’s lip. The river does not mind that we fear it, so long as we are honest about that fear and do not pass it off as policy. In the rite we will weigh breath against brine, bell against hush, and if the scale tips true the sluice-gates will move as easily as a promise kept. Stand close when the flood-song builds, Thalen Vire, for the Judge hears not words alone but the weight behind them, and light hearts can be heavier than iron when they carry a city’s thirst.

dialogue.speaker: Thalen Vire
dialogue.lines: I have names written in hush-ink that fade at dawn and silt under my nails that will not wash away, and both kinds of truth are heavy when the water listens. I’ll take the old empire’s marching measure from the pass and lay it across these stairs, and I’ll hold the line with my own breath if raiders come ghosting on the flood to cut the ropes again. If the Judge asks what the city owes, I will answer without ornament: we owe upstream breath, not excuses, and we owe a clean glass of water before we polish our lenses. I have a bell that can calm an eddy and a conch that forces tongues to wait their turn, and I will use both if the rite shakes apart under the weight of panic. I am bound to a promise I tossed into the Blue Maw when I was young and unwise, and if I must bring the city to stillness for the bells to be heard, then let the sea judge me afterward but not the children who drink from bowls of air.

dialogue.speaker: Orven Caldris
dialogue.lines: Public rites make poor policy and worse contracts, and I say this as one who has seen how quickly crowds trade principle for spectacle when lanterns are lit. We can restructure flows without theater, without bruising those levers that keep the city’s heart beating, and certainly without humiliating the Diadem in front of stair-villages that mistake sentiment for solvency. Your maps are stolen and your accusations are embroidered with damp thread; bring them into a proper chamber with seals, witnesses, and counterweights, and we will do what is necessary with a steady hand. The river does not sign contracts and it does not keep books, and yet you would put a city under the judgment of a current that has drowned better men than you. Return to your charts and your bells, novice and mediator alike, and leave the debt to those of us who can carry it without crying to river ghosts and without collapsing the price of bread by ringing at the wrong hour.

dialogue.speaker: Rae Fen
dialogue.lines: You can carry coin, Mask, but can you carry thirst when the bells do not ring and the steps go dry, or will you weigh water like you weigh gossip and call it even when the cups are empty. The Judge knows the difference between a ledger that balances and a life that does, and it can taste the salt in a lie as quickly as a fish tastes blood. Stand aside and let the bells do the work the terraces carved into them with years and hands, or stand with us and learn how to listen to something that does not care for masks. Either way, when the flood comes over the seventh step the ropes must be mended and the ringers must be guarded, because the cut was made by those who would turn silence into profit. The bells will ring, and if they ring cracked, the sound will still find the Judge, and the Judge will still find you.

choices.title: Indict in the open: ring the full measure and name the bleed-valves before the crowd and the Judge.
choices.text: You climb the shrine’s wet steps and tie the last knot with a tug that stings your palms, then raise the striker for all to see so no one can claim the sound was an accident. You speak names and places as if uncoiling a rope, describing hidden bleed-valves, altered ledgers, and nights when the aqueduct’s whisper turned coarse with theft. You signal Blue Fist escorts with a rooftop code to hold a human ring around the bell-ringers, and their drum answers throb through the reedboats like another heart. You refuse Orven’s parchment and its tidy compromises, declaring that a clean cup upstream is worth a week of sour looks in the Diadem, and your voice gathers the hush around it the way a keel gathers wake. When the bells swing you strike hard and true, letting the old imperial measure walk the stairs in thunder, and you hold your breath so the Judge can hear your courage in the spaces between each note.
choices.outcome: The Judge rises first as a prickle in every throat and then as a cool shadow that tastes of silt and winter reed, and it lifts the sound into a stillness that is not silence but attention. Terraces chant the measure back in waves, and when you pour your evidence into the conchs the brine curls around the lies and spits them as white foam that smells faintly of ink, to the crowd’s low growl. Ys Hul intones the rebalancing and the sluice-gates move with a groan like old ribs, sending a ribbon of sweet water over dry steps without dimming the city’s lamps more than a breath, and you feel children’s laughter snag on the rope and flutter like pennants. Orven’s masks depart with stiff bows that promise winter, and Ledger clerks begin scouring contracts for claws, but the terraces mark your face and your oath in bead and cord, and Blue Fist stewards clasp your shoulder in public daylight. When you march the testimony downriver, the Aethral Archive’s blue panes shiver around the spoken record and grant the seal as if the building itself wished to sign, and word runs ahead of you that the Choir’s standing has risen and that the Judge’s Bead has found your throat.

choices.title: Keep the rite pure: hide the names from the crowd, give them to the Judge and the Archive only.
choices.text: You tie the bell-lines with hands that make no flourish and teach the ringers to breathe on your count, choosing rhythm over rage. You take Rae’s trembling list and your own hush-marked notes and fold them inside the Conch of Slack Water, resolving that the Judge will hear and that the mob will not be offered a spark. You walk the row of Blue Fist guards and Tidewardens both, reminding them that oaths were made under blue light and that some battles are won by not striking first, and even the hard-eyed ones lower their chins. When Orven comes with his careful sneer you refuse both his ink and his bait, promising in even tones that there will be a reckoning in proper chambers once the river has weighed the city’s breath. You step back at the moment of ringing and let Rae’s hands speak, holding your bell close to crib the swell if it runs hot, and you count out the old measure under your breath for those who trust your timing.
choices.outcome: The Judge gathers like dew, soft and cold, and the bell tones fall into it as neatly as drops in a bowl, each one rippling outward to kiss every ear on the seventh step. When you pour the names into the conch at slack water, the sound does not carry to the crowd, but the river takes it all the same, and the brine crawling at the shrine’s edge turns dark for a heartbeat as if swallowing a secret. Ys Hul declares a measured rebalancing, and the gates answer obediently, giving the terraces a sip that tastes of apology without provoking panic in the city where lamp-wrights fret. Orven nods as if you have grown, already calculating how to bargain in chambers where walls do not echo, but he does not snatch the moment, and his clerks retreat to sharpen quills rather than knives. The Archive receives your sealed testimony with quiet ceremony, affixing a seal that frees you from Ledger counters, and though the terraces whisper that you were too gentle, their elders send grain and a bead to show that gentleness can still weigh heavy.

choices.title: Seize stillness: invoke the hush bound in your silt-bell to hold the swell while the ringers work.
choices.text: You feel the flood arriving like a drum you can hear through your bones, and you know the knots are true but the timing is fragile as spun glass. You cradle the Third-Tone Silt-Bell and angle your Azure Lens to read the river’s mood, seeing a raggedness in the surface that tells you saboteurs will strike in the rattle between tones. You take a breath that tastes of old vows and Blue Maw cold, then ring the bell not for sound but for shape, sending a quiet through the steps that behaves like a scaffold around the rite. Rae looks to you and nods, and you motion the ringers to their marks as the hush settles, steady enough to thread a rope through a needle, and the saboteurs’ footsteps falter when their courage cannot find its echo. Orven flinches at the unnatural calm and spits that you have weaponized weather, but your hands do not shake because you know the price and are willing to count it aloud later if you must.
choices.outcome: The stillness holds like a held breath over a cup, letting Rae’s hammers fall with precision no storm could corrupt, and the measure walks the stairs so perfectly that even the old crumbling stones seem to stand taller. The saboteurs try their cut and find themselves moving through molasses, their blades rasping without music, and Blue Fist hands bind them with cords whose knots remember better days. Yet a bell-ringer staggers under the hush that brushes too close to his heart, and you see the shadow of your earlier sin at Moonhook Docks pass across his face before he steadies, and you know the river has noticed what you borrowed. The Judge rises curious and close, studying not only your evidence but your theft, and when Ys Hul calls the rebalancing the gates obey but the hush nips your heel like a tide-dog claiming a debt. The terraces bless you, the Choir embraces you, the Archive grants its seal, but the Tidewardens mark your bell’s tone with tight mouths, and Orven files a phrase that will one day call your silence criminal if the Court grows thirsty for scapegoats.

choices.title: Cut a bargain: accept Orven’s guards and strings in exchange for delaying public naming until after the rite.
choices.text: You read the stairs and the crowd and judge that a fight today will drown tomorrow’s work, and you lift two fingers to the mask to talk in the practical language of timing. You demand immediate protection for bell-ringers and shrine steps, cordons that keep raiders at reed’s length, and a written pledge that the Archive will receive your testimony untouched by Ledger counters within one tide. You bind the promise with the Conch of Slack Water so his words cannot interrupt yours, and you lay out the terms as slowly as you would step across Shattermere: not one bell silenced, not one knot cut, not one ringer dismissed for fear. You instruct Rae and Ys Hul in a whisper that the names will be spoken in chambers under blue light, and that the Judge will receive the truth in the conch at the end of the rite rather than at the start, because the first duty is to ring the measure clean. You ignore Orven’s smugness as the guards take position, and you keep your eyes on the ropes and the children and the sky that leans closer whenever a city is about to lie to itself.
choices.outcome: The rite proceeds without a blade flashing in the crowd, and the bells walk the imperial cadence down the terraces until even the reeds clap, and you know you bought that space with coin you will pay later in trust. Ledger guards hold their lines and the saboteurs slink away, unwilling to tangle with muscle that answers to coin more quickly than to conscience, and the ringers finish with shoulders unbruised. Ys Hul delivers the rebalancing and the sluice-gates sigh open like relieved lungs, and though the ribbon of water is thinner than justice it is thicker than despair, and many cups are filled. Later, in chambers washed by oath-lantern blue, you speak the names into the conch and the Archive etches them into glass with a hiss, and Orven signs without pleasure because the river has already weighed him and he would rather be seen yielding than be seen dragged. The terraces send you grain and a bead but their elders look at you as one looks at a bridge built of twine, while the Ledger marks a line under your name that reads useful until troublesome, and the Choir gives you a nod that means you walked a narrow board and did not fall.
